summary: The document is a confidential memorandum detailing U.S. operational plans to counteract Nikita Khrushchev's visit to Cuba, perceived as a move to strengthen Soviet influence in Cuba and Latin America. Strategies involved organizing a church rally in Cuba to show opposition and spreading rumors of an assassination attempt on Khrushchev to discourage his visit. The memo underscores the importance of safeguarding CIA assets in Cuba during these operations.
key_findings: The U.S. government perceived Khrushchev's potential visit to Cuba as a significant threat to increase Soviet influence in Latin America.
Countermeasures included internal opposition via church rallies and external propaganda regarding assassination threats.
The CIA prioritized the protection of its assets in Cuba to prevent their exposure.
Collaboration with Latin American countries was sought to enhance opposition efforts and rumor dissemination.
The document reveals the strategic use of media and controlled agents to influence public perception and spread information.
